2.text:
Samantha Wilson:– Thank you Ian, my name’s
Samantha and for the last six months I was

7.text:
lucky enough to photograph, catalogue and
research some of the 8,000 objects that were

13.text:
donated by Duncan Grant and Vanessa Bell’s
daughter, Angelica, to the Charleston Trust

17.text:
in 2008 as part of the Angelica Garnett Gift.
In the early 20th century, Vanessa Bell’s

24.text:
painting and decorative work placed her at
the forefront of British Modernism yet she

28.text:
feared succumbing to the usual female fate
of not being taken seriously as an artist,

33.text:
and today is often examined as a member of
a wider group or as one half of a couple.

38.text:
This research considers the uneasy relationship
between the eyes of the mother and that of

42.text:
the artist, and how the emotional attachment
of one, can cause conflict for the practical

46.text:
detachment of the other.
This talk we’ll discuss an object found

50.text:
early in exploration of the Gift; a sketchbook
by Vanessa Bell containing sketches of her

55.text:
infant son, Julian Hewett Bell, who was later
killed in the Spanish Civil War. Deborah Cherry,

62.text:
author of ‘Victorian Women Artists’, describes
how by the mid-19th century, what marked a

68.text:
woman as a practising and professional artist;
was a sale of works, taking part in exhibitions

75.text:
or the acceptance of commissions. In other
words, her art must be in the public sphere.

80.text:
Whilst Bell made notable appearances in exhibitions
at the beginning of her career, she also kept

85.text:
private sketchbooks filled with observations
of people and places that intrigued her. The

90.text:
sketchbook found in the Gift is an interesting
object, covered in vellum; we know it was

95.text:
purchased on a trip Bell took to Italy in
1904. In a letter to her friend, Margery Snowden

101.text:
dated 25 April. Bell describes that she has
purchased some very nice drawing books with

107.text:
vellum covers and real old paper, which is
much nicer than any modern paper and quite

113.text:
cheap.
As part of my research I have also found a

116.text:
record of Bell discussing what may have been
the sketchbook in a letter to her sister Virginia

121.text:
Woolf, in the autumn of 1908 where she complains,
“...what wouldn’t I give for a steady

127.text:
uninterrupted two months’ work” and talks
of her accomplishing some vague sketches of

132.text:
Julian. All objects in the Gift are valuable
in their own way, but there is something very

138.text:
precious about the 1908 sketchbook, even before
you know what is in it. Bell talked about

143.text:
how old paper is much nicer than anything
modern and looking at and holding the sketchbook,

148.text:
you can really understand what she meant.
There is a timeless almost mystical quality

152.text:
about the object and although it’s tempting
to get swept along with the romantic notions

156.text:
of the Bloomsbury childhood, once you look
at the variety of sketches inside you realise

161.text:
that it contain so much more. Part of the
fascination that this sketchbook holds, is

166.text:
that it is not just a mother drawing idealistic
drawings of her child, it also offers insight

171.text:
of how the mind of the artist was working
and developing.

176.text:
Quentin Bell, the second son born to...the
second child born to Vanessa and Clive Bell,

181.text:
points out that to his mother, the sketch
was always of more interest than the finished

185.text:
product, it being the result of an initial
thought process and full of potential. The

191.text:
book and the sketches within it, represents
a mother’s love for her first-born child

196.text:
but it is also an indication of Bell’s desire
to explore a constantly changing subject through

201.text:
quick sketches and constant observations.
It echoes the functions of other sketchbooks

206.text:
we have found in the Gift, which contain drawings
and designs to the Omega Workshop, theatre

211.text:
productions and the portraits of strangers.
What sets this sketchbook apart from others

216.text:
in the Gift is that Bell’s focus of constant
observation is her son, a maternal and domestic

222.text:
subject.
We can presume that these sketches were preparatory

226.text:
works for the oil paintings Bell produced
of Julian, which now hang in her bedroom at

230.text:
Charleston and were not exhibited during Bell’s
lifetime. One of the paintings has since been

236.text:
exhibited in the 2006 exhibition ‘From Victorian
to Modern: Innovation and Tradition in the

241.text:
Work of Vanessa Bell, Gwen John and Laura
Knight’. The sketchbook creates an opportunity

247.text:
to consider the relationship between the eye
of the mother and that of the artist and how

251.text:
Bell dealt with this conflict in her artwork
and in her life. This conflict is in part

257.text:
a result of the contradiction between being
pregnant, a creative activity which serves

262.text:
to exclude women from the public sphere and
being a creative artist, an activity which

267.text:
requires a woman to propel herself to the
public sphere in spite of her gender.

273.text:
Maternal and domestic duty was thrust upon
Bell at a young age following the death of

276.text:
her mother and step-sister. This duty was
at times in great conflict with her desire

282.text:
to paint. Becoming a mother herself was a
prospect in 1907 that appeared unsettling

288.text:
to Bell, as demonstrated in a letter she wrote
to Virginia Woolf in 1907; “I am honestly

294.text:
terrified sometimes of the responsibility
of having any children, I’m not sure it

299.text:
doesn’t mean the most...hanging the most
horrific millstone around one’s neck. I

303.text:
can look at it calmly now but when I have
them I shall probably be so unreasonably fond

308.text:
of them that it won’t strike me in that
light. But all the same, I doubt if I shall

312.text:
be a good parent, I think I shall probably
hate the practical part too much.”

316.text:
Whilst Clive Bell encouraged his wife’s
commitment to painting and developing her

321.text:
art, it is certain that he felt displaced
by Bell’s preoccupation with her son. As

327.text:
he was alarmed by the noise and disorder brought
to her household by children, he left most

332.text:
of the maternal work to mother and nurse;
like most fathers at this time. Clive wrote

337.text:
complaining to Woolf in December 1908 that,
“I do not even sleep with her; the baby

342.text:
takes up all her time.” The wedge that Julian’s
birth drove into the Bells’ marriage eventually

348.text:
resulted in a short flirtation with Woolf.
This exposed limitations of Clive’s love

353.text:
and of the Bells’ marriage. Although they
did not remain married in a romantic sense,

358.text:
their friendship was an important part of
Bell’s life and it may have been that she

362.text:
was not overtly interested in marriage as
a concept in any circumstance.

367.text:
Before accepting Clive’s proposal, she remarked
that she could be happy living, “...with

372.text:
anyone whom I didn’t dislike, if I could
paint and lead the kind of life I like.”

377.text:
In contrast, the relationship between mother
and son was never to weaken and Julian absorbed

382.text:
Bell’s interest almost to the point of obsession.
It was only with the birth of Quintin in 1910

388.text:
that Bell’s anxiety was modified and whilst,
like many artists, she used sketches and portraits

395.text:
of all three of her children during her career,
we are yet to find other examples of such

401.text:
a complete and private contemplation of motherhood
such as this sketchbook. In fact, until much

408.text:
later in her career, when Bell chose to include
her children in her artworks, she used them

413.text:
more as props for the themes rather than representing
them as themselves. They are more often than

418.text:
not painted without the loving eye of the
mother and instead with the discerning eye

423.text:
of the artist.
Writing for the ‘New York Times’, arts

427.text:
and culture writer Jacoba Urist discussed
the concept of the ‘mother-artist’ and

432.text:
the accepted wisdom that female artists who
reproduce will spend several years producing

438.text:
idiosyncratic, excessively inward looking
‘baby art’. Then she writes, if they are

444.text:
lucky they will eventually get their wits
about them and return to more serious work.

449.text:
Some of the images in the 1908 sketchbook
could be accused of being overtly sentimental

453.text:
and obvious expressions of a mother’s love,
and in Bell’s case obsession with her infant

459.text:
child. These sketches represent the eye of
the mother and the love that she has for her

464.text:
child. However, many of the images showed
developments in the way that Bell was seeing

469.text:
and interpreting her subject. In particular
the hastily captured drawings of Julian moving

475.text:
are in great contrast to the sensitive depictions
of him sleeping. These quick drawings appear

481.text:
to be more of an exercise in art, rather than
the act of recording the early stages of childhood.

487.text:
Working almost obsessively in a repeated process
of capturing a single subject in various states

492.text:
of movement, these sketches seem more detached
in a practical way from maternal feeling.

498.text:
In this sense some of the images within the
sketchbook can be compared to Eadweard Muybridge’s

502.text:
photographs of movement and George Stubbs’s
preoccupation with the horse. All three artists

508.text:
reflecting the desire to document, in a timeless
fashion, physical shapes and movement and

513.text:
a preoccupation with a single theme. The 1908
sketchbook was produced before Bell became

519.text:
influenced by the concept of significant form
and the Post-Impressionist exhibitions of

528.text:
must have presented great liberation for Bell,
from the artistic ideals of the Victorian

533.text:
era and the Royal Academy of Arts. Fry called
for art that was expressive even when it was

538.text:
largely divorced from what we recognise as
reality. The relationship between lines, colours,

544.text:
shapes and other properties that made up an
image were infinitely more vital to its success

549.text:
than the subject it represented.
Despite the difficulties in their marriage,

554.text:
Clive Bell, as an art critic remained a source
of information and inspiration to Bell. During

560.text:
this time she would have been surrounded with
discussions of change and experimentation

563.text:
in art. The movement we can see in some of
these early drawings of Julian are representative

569.text:
of the way Bell worked as her painting, drawing,
and ideas about modern art developed. For

574.text:
Bell it became not the subject matter of a
painting or drawing that was important, but

578.text:
the way in which she could transfer ideas
onto the canvas. Experiments meant research

583.text:
and technique and composition, rather than
radical changes in the subjects and genre

588.text:
she painted. In discussions with Fry, Bell
came to the conclusion that a near-likeness

594.text:
to nature was meaningless unless it expressed
an idea or emotion. Like in these early drawings

599.text:
of Julian, a subject was to be broken into
a series of lines and marks, rather than accurate

605.text:
and personal representations of friends and
family. Bell argued that her subject was,

611.text:
“...this painter’s world of form and colour.”
Child portraiture is a subject that has been

616.text:
explored throughout art history, it is common
for the artist to want to explore the theme

621.text:
of childhood and there are many reasons why
they would want to create images of their

625.text:
own children. These range from the desire
to capture their child in a golden age of

629.text:
innocence to the fact that being near at hand,
an artist’s child was a convenient model

634.text:
for works, where they are disguised in other
roles, such as Bell’s murals in Berwick

640.text:
Church. Whilst the sketchbook of Julian is
a private piece, Bell also painted works with

646.text:
maternal and domestic themes for public exhibitions.
Some of these have been described as her most

653.text:
important Post-Impressionist paintings.
Painted in 1913, ‘Woman and Baby’, a work

660.text:
that is now only known by photograph, was
one painting which was considered this. A

664.text:
review of the Grafton Group Exhibition where
it was hung proclaimed it, “...one of the

670.text:
most poignant designs that one remembers in
modern painting. It has an intensely human

675.text:
interest, clothed in a primitive passion that
seems to sweep aside all conventional barriers.

680.text:
None but a woman, none but a great artist,
could have so perfectly expressed, with a

685.text:
new sympathy, all the pathos and bewilderment
of this time-worn theme.”

694.text:
Despite the obvious reference to maternal
experience, Bell chooses to reduce the figures

698.text:
to almost flat silhouettes and all detail
is omitted. Recent experiments that resulted

705.text:
in the faceless portraits of Woolf, led Bell
to find that even with a blank face, character

710.text:
and emotion could be conveyed simply by the
positioning of a head on a canvas. This painting

716.text:
is far removed from the sentimental ‘baby
art’ that we see in the sleeping sketches

720.text:
of Julian in the 1908 sketchbook. In this
painting the eye of the mother is detached

725.text:
from the theme, a traditional domestic and
feminine scene is made modern as Bells use

730.text:
of abstraction makes each shape static and
separate.

734.text:
‘Nursery Tea’, painted in 1912 was a painting
which Bell considered entirely new in its

741.text:
manner, and she expressed her excitement with
experimentation in a letter to Fry on the

745.text:
5 June 1911; “I’m trying to paint as if
I were mosaicking, not by painting in spots

752.text:
but by considering the picture as patches,
each of which has to be filled by one definite

757.text:
space of colour. It’s amusing to make these
experiments, even if they don’t succeed.”

763.text:
Bloomsbury biographer, Frances Spalding, has
commented that the sweep of certain lines

768.text:
in the painting such as the curve of the table
cloth, are reflective of Bell’s maternal

773.text:
experience. An interesting observation when
one considers that the red-headed child is

778.text:
thought to be Bell’s second son Quentin.
Despite perhaps being in part a portrait of

784.text:
the artist’s child, this is another painting
where Bell works in omitting the facial features

789.text:
of the figures, instead they communicate via
the shapes of their bodies and the tilt of

793.text:
their heads. It is interesting to consider
the shapes of the figures in the image and

798.text:
compare them to the hastily completed sketches
of Julian in the 1908 sketchbook. We can see

803.text:
that in both images, Bell uses a mix of straight
and curved lines to create the body of a child;

809.text:
there is no sensitive detailing of eyes, hands
or indeed any other body part that makes a

815.text:
child unique and recognisable to its parents.
In these paintings, Bell managed to convey

821.text:
the experience of motherhood without turning
to anecdotal sentimentality. The subject may

826.text:
be maternal but the eye of the artist is concerned
with experiment and the avant-garde, rather

832.text:
than personal experience and emotion.
The art world is full of enduring stereotypes

838.text:
from those of the starving artist to the artist
in the grip of insanity. The stereotype that

843.text:
is interesting to this discussion is that
of the childless artist, a woman who is so

847.text:
dedicated to developing her craft that there
is no time or space in life for motherhood.

853.text:
I say that the childless artist is considered
to be female, because throughout art history

859.text:
and history in general, many women have been
denied access to the public sphere or the

863.text:
creative art world. They have been restricted
to the private and domestic sphere and to

869.text:
contemplate a serious career like their male
contemporaries, meant denying their reproductive

874.text:
difference and eliminating ideas for the maternal
from both their private life and their public

878.text:
artwork. Unlike Bell, her sister Virginia
Woolf is widely renowned as a genius. Her

884.text:
work considered ground-breaking, controversial,
and an important contribution to literature

888.text:
of the 20th century and beyond. Both sisters
grew up in a typical Victorian household and

894.text:
Woolf described them by nature as “...explorers,
revolutionists and reformers”, who were

900.text:
living in surroundings at least 50 years behind
the times.

903.text:
Bell’s own daughter, Angelica, wrote in
her autobiography that while Woolf gained

909.text:
world recognition there was some element of
Bell which refused to compete, forcing her

914.text:
to restrict her energies to a more personal
area where she reigned supreme. Whilst we

920.text:
must acknowledge that Angelica was highly
subjective when writing about her mother and

924.text:
that due to their turbulent relationship there
may have been some hidden agenda to Angelica’s

928.text:
words. It is also important to remember that
this is a reoccurring assessment of Bell’s

933.text:
life and career.
Whilst both sisters married later in life

937.text:
than was strictly conventional; Bell was the
one who went on to have children. These two

942.text:
women were both artists in their separate
fields, both from the same background yet

946.text:
one is considered a childless genius and another’s
maternal role and appointment as ‘high priestess’

952.text:
of Bloomsbury, has often overshadowed her
work as an artist. Whilst this distinction

957.text:
could be the result of the role Bell took
on as a young woman, as a carer of her sister

962.text:
and family, it is still an interesting point
to consider that in literature about Bell,

967.text:
we are constantly reminded and told of the
domestic roles that she has played and that

972.text:
it is only recently and with some detail,
that her career as an artist is being re-evaluated.

979.text:
The sisters themselves seem to be aware of
this basic maternal difference, with Woolf

983.text:
writing to Bell in 1926 following Bell’s
success at the London Artist Association Exhibition,

990.text:
and commenting; “I am amazed, a little alarmed,
for as you have the children, the fame by

995.text:
rights belongs to me.” Bell was conscious
and concerned about the barriers motherhood

1000.text:
might represent to the progression of her
art. Writing to Woolf in 1909, shortly after

1005.text:
the birth of Julian, she complained; “in
any case your art seems to be progressing

1010.text:
and ascending, whilst mine is under the heel
of Moo-cows”, which was the infant Julian’s

1016.text:
name for his mother. It could appear at times
that the two were in a rivalry to live a life

1021.text:
identified with the artistic, despite their
different domestic situations.

1026.text:
Woolf set out to prove herself, as she says
that, “being childless I was less normal

1030.text:
than she.” While Bell implies that her sister
is settled and unadventurous, calling attention

1035.text:
to her own love of travel and exploration
of different cultures. In response to this,

1041.text:
Woolf commented that in Bell’s case, motherdom
was to be compensated for, not just by hard

1046.text:
work but also by a certain displacement to
prevent solidity from setting in. This brings

1052.text:
forth the idea of martyrdom and sacrifice
and begs the question, did Bell herself believe

1057.text:
as others did, that she sacrificed one world
for the other and to what degree, if she did

1063.text:
her all did she consider herself a martyr?
Bell has been described as having a life packed

1068.text:
like a cabinet of drawers, with Duncan Grant,
the children, painting and Roger Fry being

1074.text:
the cause of sapping her artistic creativity.
And it’s sometimes viewed that her maternal

1079.text:
role detracted in some way from her primary
need to communicate her vision through paint.

1084.text:
Whilst Woolf asserted that by rights she was
entitled to fame as a result of her childless

1089.text:
state, she sympathised with what she saw as
a sacrifice her sister has made, and imagine

1095.text:
that after all the children had left, that
Bell would, “...go back, rather sadly to

1101.text:
the life she would have liked best of all,
to be a painter on her own.”

1106.text:
With hindsight, we know that Bell’s most
experimental and most critically-valued work

1110.text:
was produced in the early years of her children’s
lives. Despite this, Bell seemed aware of

1116.text:
the limitations that motherhood could place
on a woman’s creativity. In a letter to

1120.text:
her daughter, Angelica, shortly after her
controversial marriage to David “Bunny”

1125.text:
Garnett, Bell wrote, “...it’s so terribly
difficult to paint seriously when one is responsible

1130.text:
for other things and hasn’t room and space
to oneself. And we females have to struggle

1136.text:
for it all our lives one way or another.”
Bell enjoyed early success by the ‘20s was

1143.text:
representative of a genuinely significant
British Modernism and has been described as

1147.text:
been synonymous with early Post-Impressionism.
But critics have accused her of, “...subsiding

1153.text:
into a slow burning reflection of her immediate
world”, later in her career. With the maternal

1158.text:
and sentimental portraits of her grandchildren
and repetitive subject matter being the main

1163.text:
cause of criticism, even though we know that
she valued experimenting technique more highly

1168.text:
than changes in subject matter. She has been
described by a critic as possessing “a lavender

1173.text:
talent”, a title which seems at odds with
the experiment in artistic insight of her

1179.text:
youth. We know that Bell was not precious
about her work and did not collect her pieces

1183.text:
with sentimental abandon.
During the Second World War when a bomb fell

1188.text:
next to her workshop at 8 Fitzroy Street,
Duncan Grant described that, “...Vanessa

1194.text:
takes it all very philosophically and says
she can always paint more pictures.” The

1198.text:
very fact then that this sketchbook purchased
in 1904, and completed in 1908 still exists

1205.text:
as part of the Gift is at odds with the attitude
Bell usually held towards her artwork.

1210.text:
After Julian’s death in 1937, Bell recalled
her early days of motherhood and her early

1216.text:
drawings of him in her diary; “Sitting at
a long window, looking onto the square with

1221.text:
him on my lap, Clive beside me, intense peace
and joy. Painting him in his cradle every

1226.text:
morning as he lay and kicked, drawing as he
began to stagger about, I still have those.”

1233.text:
This quote is fascinating because it tells
us that the 1908 sketchbook remains a part

1237.text:
of the Gift because Bell chose to preserve
it separate from her position as a celebrated

1242.text:
artist.
Bell kept this sketchbook with the love and

1245.text:
emotional attachment associated with the eye
of the mother. In another quote taken from

1251.text:
a letter to Julian’s former lover in 1939
Bell remarked, “I really pity people who

1257.text:
are not artists with no refuge from the world.
Life would be intolerable if one could not

1262.text:
get detached from it.” What this quote implies
is, as an artist Bell believed her work was

1268.text:
detached from the world she inhabited, this
is the practical detachment of the eye of

1272.text:
the artist. At first, this sketchbook could
be interpreted as a mother’s personal record

1278.text:
and visual representation of love for her
first born child, yet by looking at the images

1283.text:
in the book and by researching other works
with maternal themes by Bell, clear distinctions

1288.text:
can be made about the sketches the book contains.
Although the sketchbook does contain loving

1294.text:
images of her child, it does not mean - and
it is evident in her work - that every time

1299.text:
she painted a child or domestic scene the
motivation was her own maternal experience

1303.text:
or emotional attachments. While there may
have been tension between her role as mother

1308.text:
and artist, at the early stages of her career
at least, it appears that she maintained a

1313.text:
separation between the two. And this sketchbook
offers a wonderful opportunity to consider

1319.text:
Vanessa Bell living and working as both maternal
figure and as an artist.

1324.text:
It was a privilege to work at Charleston and
with the items in the Angelica Garnett Gift,

1329.text:
and it’s been a wonderful experience to
share my research with you today. This sketchbook

1334.text:
was just one object amidst 8,000, so if you
want to learn anymore about the Gift, the

1339.text:
new interns do have a blog, so charlestonattic
is really good. Okay, thank you very much.
